values: Just saw this movie on HBO.  Despite missing some pretty major plot points (my roommate's TV is nice looking, but its speakers are easily drowned out by my own coughing), I thought it was pretty damn good.  So good it prompted me to post about it on my Livejournal.

You know that prodding feeling of inadequacy that completely destroys you every few months/weeks/days/hours? Yeah, it's that time again. It's the usual suspect this time--a casual stroll through DeviantArt's good avenues drove a pike into my at-the-time vulnerable ego. I should be doing something heartwarmingly nostalgic right now...

It truly is.



This is a work-in-progress on a "cover" for a comic I've been trying to make for years with the current working title of "The Railway."

Against the backdrop of a WWI-esque political climate, the story focuses on three childhood friends that are separated by various factors relating to the war. One enlists in the army, another is accepted to a distant technical university, and one stays behind. The story follows their individual comings of age as they try to adapt with their new and constantly changing worlds, especially when the conflict abroad comes much, much closer to home.

And it's a fantasy epic.

This is one of the first paintings I've tried without using pressure-dependent opacity on the brush, and I have to say, it feels much more controlled and solid. If you look at some of my other paintings (The May 31 post, in particular. But it's much more evident in pictures I haven't posted.) there's always a glut in shades, all due to the spontaneity in the brush's opacity. Colors are mixed haphazardly and with little thought, leaving me with pretty bad stroke economy.

This way is different, though. A good portion of the hues and values you see here were hand-picked and actually flatted. Only after did I start blending, and this time by manually changing brush opacity. It feels much more like pixelling this way, and the result feels more solid and sharp than usual.

</artfag>

I admit it.  I don't know two shits about color.

And I fucked up the light sources too.  How the hell did I miss that?

I should be doing more collegiate-like things.

First are a few drawings and pixels of Hero Town, the last project my school's Game Development club considered before fading into obscurity, as most first forays into the industry often do. Second are miscellaneous Photoshop sketches from the past two months. I should be a bit more concerned about graduation...

<lj-cut text="It is.">

Now, if you'll excuse me, I'm off to send a death threat to Jack Thompson.

I should be applying for scholarships...
I should be getting around to those college applications.
I should be applying for colleges...and fixing this damned chair.
I should be writing...something...

So, I just post insignificant details of my uneventful life as if they were worth talking about, right?  That is how it works, does it not?

I should be getting ready to go to work.

Lord Almighty, what in blazes have I done?

I dunno.  Maybe I should've gone with a red base color for the userpic.  Could've been more intense.  Right now it looks a bit too somber.

I should be updating at blogspot.
